posts.name: sam liu
posts.cooked: Our team wants to use 1 Kracken X60 to power our elevator. However, the elevator is too heavy, so I must set the current limit to 80 Amps to maximize the efficiency. I trust Kracken X60’s robust cooling system, but I’m concerned that this will trigger the 40A breaker. So, can I use two PDP channels to power one Kracken X60 motor, to get a consistent 80 Amps output?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: No.  See R621. “Each branch circuit must be protected by 1 and only 1 circuit breaker or fuse”

posts.name: Tauseef Afraz
posts.cooked: Also, if you have 2 slots, you should use 2 motors

posts.name: Jeffrey Morris
posts.cooked:
catrix:

to get a consistent 80 Amps output?

Reminder that current limits are exactly that, limits. Setting an 80A current limit does not mean you will be pulling 80A consistently.

You should have a look at the datasheet for the breaker, unlike a fuse, breakers can go over their rating for an extended period of time depending on how far you exceed it. (And in the case of rev breakers… lets just call this time EXTREMELY generous )

posts.name: Allen Nuttle
posts.cooked:
Hard no.  And, you would be running the motor near maximum inefficiency, near stall.  The right answer is you need gearing, and/or two motors.  At near-stall torque, almost 100% of the electrical energy you are putting into the motor is being turned to heat.  And, with an elevator, you probably have to run the motor to hold position, so you’re looking at 12V (nominal) * 40A (in reality, very likely to be considerably higher) = 480W, for most of the match.

I’m not sure what the rate the motor can dissipate this energy (it’s a function of how hot it gets), but there’s a good chance it will keep heating and, at some point, fail.  Add a gearbox, and also consider doubling up the motors.

posts.name: neev dadhania
posts.cooked:
DAflamingFOX:

And in the case of rev breakers… lets just call this time EXTREMELY generous

150.67 KB

posts.name: sam liu
posts.cooked:
nuttle:

you need gearing

I’m planning to use a 4:1 reduction. I’ve tried different gear ratios on ReCalc and this one gives me the lowest time-to-goal, only 0.6s.

image 2134×1365 222 KB

image 2134×1365 222 KB

image 2134×1365 222 KB

But as soon as I lower the current limit to 40 Amps, the time-to-goal becomes 1.76s.

image 2068×996 137 KB

image 2068×996 137 KB

posts.name: Mithul Balasubramanian
posts.cooked: If the shorter time to goal is important, then running a current limit higher than 40A should be fine. Just make sure that you don’t consistently brown out or trip a fuse/breaker.

posts.name: Emerson OHara
posts.cooked:
catrix:

must set the current limit to 80 Amps

This seems like a lot unless you’re geared really fast, id recommend more gear reduction or 2 motors to share the load, but also evaluate where the load is coming from.

Fwiw 80A STATOR current limit does not mean 80A on the supply unless the output is basically 100% duty cycle. You could set the supply current limit to 40A and stator to 80A and basically be set as far as the breaker goes.

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked: Hey- if all you need is 200% power for 5 seconds, this is a great solution

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
catrix:

I’m planning to use a 4:1 reduction. I’ve tried different gear ratios on ReCalc and this one gives me the lowest time-to-goal, only 0.6s.

I would go a couple levels up from that, maybe a 6:1. I’d say 5:1 but those tend to be in short supply. Or add a second Kraken.

Time-to-goal is not the be-all and end-all, for a specific subsystem. You need to be able to move this elevator despite it getting knocked around. You need to be able to deposit the Coral quickly, yes… but anything around 1 second will be adequate for MOST events. (If you advance to DCMP or CMP , that’s not MOST events, but you’ll have some small time to adjust.) Particularly if your Coral Placer is a little bit slower.

posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked: I recommend looking at Mechanism Startup Calculator - AMB Robotics Calculator you can set a current limit and see what the fastest ratio is for that current

posts.custom_user_title: FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor

posts.name: Eric Tate
posts.cooked: Just adding emphasis to this point about duty cycle. Without getting to far into the details, you can roughly assume that input current to the motor controller (what the breaker is seeing) is equal to the motor current times per unit speed. So operating at high motor current at low speed does not pull that much current through the breaker. I would be more concerned about motor heating but if it is short duration, not likely to be much of an issue.

posts.name: Dale Yocum
posts.cooked: Many teams also use constant force springs to help take some of weight of the final stage.  Look at the Thriftybot elevator for an example of that.
